reviews.text: We enjoyed our stay at the Sawanoya. The staff are exceptionally friendly and helpful. The area is wonderfully quiet with haphazard streets for exploring - a lovely respite from the frenetic energy of central Tokyo! Our room was fine, an unpleasant stale, fish oil smell that we actually experienced in all 3 ryokan we stayed at, plus I was plagued by some form of insect bites at night. I can only assume it was bed bugs of some sort, however again I experienced this in all 3 ryokan - wearing long pj trousers at all times in the room eventually sorted this out.
reviews.title: Very friendly stay at Sawanoya
Don't forget the night key
reviews.text: The public areas and bathrooms are very pleasant and clean - definitely the best of the 3 (Sawanoya, Kimi in Tokyo and Hiraiwa in Kyoto).
We were staying with a 2 year old who enjoyed himself thoroughly!
reviews.title: A very nice ryokan
Great place!!!!
reviews.text: For the money I doubt you can beat this place in Tokyo, if your down with the traditional style of a Ryokan. And if your not you should be, becuase places like this are what they are all about. Quiet, friendly, clean and tourist friendly. The neighborhood of Yanaka is very quiet, which may be exactly what your looking for if you've spent all day in Harajuku and all night in Shinjuku. Lots of temples, and art galleries. I really liked this place and wouldn't be suprised if I headed straight back for my next trip, unless I'm super rich by then. Until that time, I'll feel more than happy resting my head on a futon at Sawanoya.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: My husband and I stayed here for four days the first week of September. The owners of the inn are super friendly and helpful. The location of this inn is perfect if you don't want to stay in a noisy part of Tokyo. Also, it is a five minute walk to the subway. There were also plenty of restaurants, markets and post office nearby for any of your needs. Our room did not have a bathroom so if you want one you might need to book a good ways in advance because there were none left. However, even if you room has a shower I HIGHLY recommend the public bath they have. It was awesome! There were two, the one on the right being big enough for two. You can lock the door so its completely private and the bath is simply amazing. You can soak in the tub with a beautiful view of a small private garden.
reviews.title: Great Value, Location and Service

reviews.text: The rooms are simple and basic but clean. If you are looking for a fancy room, don't book here you will be disappointed. But if you are looking for modest accommodations, beautfiful bath, friendly inn owners and a great location, then this is the place. Also, they serve a western breakfast every morning without the need for a reservation so it made it super convenient the day we left to grab some breakfast before our journey to Kyoto.
reviews.title: Great location, friendly and clean

reviews.text: We stayed here for four nights in July. Really quiet area to stay in and within walking distance of ueno park where there are loads to see and do. The family that run the chain are very friendly and the rooms are clean, simple and very japanese. The added bonus of staying here is there two japanese baths which were wonderful! If your on a budget the western breakfasts they offer are cheap, the ryokan is close to a supermarket where you can buy food. It also has a washing machine and dryer which is cheap to use if you are back packing like we were. Plus free internet. Fantastic little place.
reviews.title: Great place to stay!

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I was traveling by myself and wanted to find a small, inexpensive ryokan in Tokyo near transportation and major sightseeing areas. Sawanoya fit the bill perfectly. The owners are great, very helpfull, the establishment is very clean, and I met a number of like minded individuals/couples/groups to network good places to go to. It is in a very safe area northof Ueno Park and just a few blocks to Chiyoda subway line to link up with other lines in the city. I enjoyed the cultural experince of staying here, also. Even though I was sharing baths and toilets, it was never a problem.
reviews.title: A lasting memory

likes.disliked: — Futons could have been a bit thicker...

reviews.text: First time to Japan - this well-renowned Ryokan was a really memorable experience for me and my wife. Perfect location - calm, friendly, very charming neighbourhood (you can't believe you're in such a big city), yet close to the metro and a few minutes ride to downtown Tokyo. Close to Ueno park with the museums and zoo. All kinds of small restaurants in the area.
reviews.title: Great place to stay

likes.disliked: — The Western-style breakfast (two pieces of white toast)

reviews.text: I stayed at Sawanoya for my first night in Japan. It was very easy to find because of the street signs actually written in English pointing out the way to go. My room was very clean and very comfortable, and there was a sink area which was not expected. The shared bathroom was also very clean. I did not use their shower facilities as my daughter (who attends the U) offered up hers to use. The staff was very friendly and accomodating and spoke decent English. Free internet use was very helpful to let friends and family back home that I had arrived safely. I did not eat there. I would not hesitate in recommending this Ryokan. It was a very nice one! Great location as well.
reviews.title: Very Nice!
Great area and value
reviews.text: Just back from Sawanoya Ryokan, read another web review with which I concur and want to add that the location is superb.
